One thing that I really, truly value about these practices is that there's no way (short of skipping ahead in the video, but we don't do that here) to make them go any faster than they're going to go. The practice is 32 minutes long, and whether I put my all into it or I slack off the whole time, I am still going to spend 32 minutes on this practice. I have looked at the clock and determined that I have those 32 minutes to spend. There is nowhere else for me to be in that time, and nowhere else I CAN be, and it takes so much pressure off my need to GO FAST.

Adriene said something early-ish in this practice about how we weren't technically doing ratio breathing, but we could think about it, and I think that ended up being incredible for my focus and presence in this session today. No, I wasn't always exactly on pace with Adriene all practice. I was on pace with MYSELF, in a steady sort of way that felt really really good. (Isn't it amazing how, when I do the breath things that this entire sequence is about doing, the sequence goes better.)

I really must call for balance here - there were a lot of spaces and asana here that were treated  very differently on one side than the other (2 balancing cat pulls-in versus 4; 1 breath in runner's stretch versus 5; pyramid pose on one side and not the other). Over time, this creates significant bodily imbalance that can take months if not years to recover from. I'm a yoga instructor, I know how hard it is to make sure that you perform the same sequence with the same timing on both sides. But it is so vitally important to make sure you do so, especially for beginners who are developing the muscular mobility, flexibility, and strength. This is not specific to this video or to Adriene, I see it all the time live and online, and I think as teachers and students it's something we have to be extra mindful of as we explore into new postures and moments!
